node.title: How a maths equation helped spark Kevin Sheedy's remarkable Australian rules career
node.alt: A photo of Kevin Sheedy standing at Royal Randwick Racecourse in 2019.
node.description: Sheedy won multiple premierships as a player and coach, andÂ shaped the game that exists today, but he could have easily been lost to cricket in his younger days.
node.content:
["It was not the passion or skill of Aussie rules football that saw Kevin Sheedy choose that sport over cricket as the one\u00a0to\u00a0dedicate a life to, and\u00a0in the process change\u00a0the face of the game and what it stands for in a broader Australian landscape.", "Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that the following article contains images and names of people who have died.", "Instead, it was a mathematical equation.", "\"The reason I chose football quite simply was that they picked 14 people in the teams, my height, and there were 12\u00a0teams in Melbourne,\" Sheedy told The Ticket.", "\"Twelve fourteens\u00a0are 168. The other sport I loved was cricket and I was a leg spinner. They only picked one [leg spinner in cricket teams]\u00a0\u2026 so I thought I'd go with the odds \u2014 168 versus one. And it paid dividends.\"", "It is hard to know where to place Sheedy's genius.", "Legend has it that while pottering in his much-loved garden in the 1990s, Sheedy devised the now hugely popular Anzac Day match between Essendon and Collingwood at the MCG.", "Sheedy wanted to pay\u00a0tribute to the Anzac spirit, having himself served two years in the army.", "Dreamtime at the 'G is another annual event out of the Sheedy box. Played between Essendon and Richmond, it combines the Indigenous spiritual belief of 'the dreaming' \u2014\u00a0described as the beginning of knowledge \u2014 with Australia's most hallowed sporting crucible, the MCG.", "It is played during the AFL's annual Indigenous round to recognise the contribution of Indigenous players to the code.", "Many of those Indigenous players came into the game because of Sheedy's personal recruitment drive, something he had committed to even before becoming a coach.", "In 1968, Australian boxer Lionel Rose \u2014 having been overlooked for the Australian Olympic team four years earlier \u2014 travelled to Tokyo to defeat Fighting Harada and claim the world bantamweight title.", "He returned to Australia a hero, with a quarter of a million people lining the streets of Melbourne to greet him upon\u00a0his arrival.", "The impact on Sheedy was profound. Rose is one of 28\u00a0Australian athletes Sheedy said\u00a0had the greatest impact on him and his life as detailed in his recent book, Icons of Sport.", "Rose was Australia's first Indigenous boxing world champion and in the same year became the first Indigenous person to be named Australian of the Year.", "", "
Sheedy was inspired by the achievements of Australian boxing great Lionel Rose (pictured).(Getty)
", "His rise was in the same period when Australians overwhelmingly voted to change the country's constitution, allowing Indigenous people to be counted in the census for the first time.", "\"You've got Lionel Rose leaving a little country town around Drouin and Warragul and [he] gets on a plane in the '60s and goes over and wins the world title in Tokyo against Fighting Harada,\" Sheedy said.", "\"Now, that was a monster decision to say to me personally, 'One day, I'm going to get into recruiting these Indigenous boys and if ever I get a coaching job \u2026 I'm going to do something about it'.\"", "Richmond, North Melbourne\u00a0and several other clubs recruited Indigenous players here and there. During his tenure as Essendon\u00a0coach\u00a0\u2014\u00a0with the club's blessing \u2014 he recruited 20 Indigenous players.", "\"I'm very proud of that,\" Sheedy said.", "\"I used to hear that many criticisms about lack of dedication, [Indigenous people] can't handle the pressure, don't know whether they can really play on the big day on the MCG \u2026 well, per head of population they've done pretty well with the Norm Smith Medal (award for best on ground in the grand final).\"", "Sheedy coached Essendon for 27\u00a0seasons between 1981 and 2007, and reached\u00a0seven grand finals, winning four of them. He won three premierships as a player with Richmond in what was then the VFL competition.", "His combined total of 929 matches\u00a0as a player and coach is a record, spanning half a century in an industry where some count themselves lucky to have an involvement of only two or three years.", "Sheedy is a member of the Sport Australia Hall of Fame and has legend status in the Australian Football Hall of Fame.", "", "
Sheedy coached Essendon from 1981 to 2007, winning four premierships in that time.(Getty: Allsport Darrin Braybrook)
", "But it would be wrong to think of Sheedy as someone whose achievements are in the past. He continues to innovate and think about the positive influence he can still bring, citing his attitude as his greatest skill.", "\"I've got a good, healthy attitude, I reckon, that's kept me vibrant,\" he said.", "\"I'm in the last quarter of my life, obviously, and I want to see more of the world, and more of my own country \u2026 [I want to] try to do more good things around our country.", "\"And I can do that now, I've got an opportunity now because there's a trust issue with Australians. If they like you, and they think they can trust your opinion, then you've got a chance, you have a chance.\"", "
Sheedy's lifelong learning
", "As the first full-time coach in VFL/AFL history, Sheedy has spent most of his life teaching others as a guide and mentor.", "For him, leadership is about sharing lessons learned from a life well spent.", "\"I think that we can learn from everybody, there's no doubt about that, I think that's probably the best way I could look at my own life,\" he said.", "\"I mean, there are just so many wonderful people in Australia.", "\"Obviously I had to go overseas and buy knowledge \u2014\u00a0lots of books, lots of videos in the '70s and '80s \u2014\u00a0and come back and apply myself to a career that no-one was doing full-time.", "\"But the only way I could do that was to go and chase \u2014 all that time [being] away from your family and your wife looking after kids for six weeks at a time after football season \u2014 and then come back and just hope you get it right.", "\"For me, many people in AFL have been wonderful. Many people in other sports, the Australian Sports Hall of Fame \u2026 and many of those incredible legendary champions I meet nearly every year \u2026 [they're]\u00a0just fantastic for me.", "\"I consider myself still young \u2014 although I'm probably cheating that a bit \u2014 but in the end I love meeting all my heroes and I love writing about them and what they meant to me.\"", "On a winter afternoon during Victoria's extended COVID-19 lockdown, Sheedy sat again\u00a0in his garden, contemplating who had inspired him \u2014\u00a0and how \u2014 through each of the decades.", "", "
Sheedy describes Melbourne Cup-winning jockey Michelle Payne (right) as a trailblazer.(Reuters: Hamish Blair)
", "Among them was Michelle Payne, the first female jockey to win the Melbourne Cup in 2015.", "\"[A] trailblazer \u2026stood her ground against officialdom to set the pathway for herself and all women jockeys,\" Sheedy said.", "Sheedy had also drawn inspiration from Jessica Watson, who in 2010 became the youngest person \u2014 at 16 \u2014\u00a0to sail solo around the world.", "\"The most courageous teenager in sport \u2014\u00a0in her craft \u2014\u00a0in my lifetime,\" he said.", "Sheedy praised the dedication of America's Cup-winning skipper and Olympic sailing medallist, John Bertrand.", "\"He studied the wind and the ocean at university to help him become a great sailor,\" Sheedy said.", "\"His watchwords were trust and purpose.\"", "And there is the story of legendary horse trainer, Bart Cummings, a man Sheedy describes as a \"classic\".", "\"I asked him what was his greatest-ever skill,\" Sheedy said.", "\"He said, 'Well, it's something a lot of people wouldn't know'. I was all ears, obviously, and I thought to myself, 'Well, what is it?'.", "\"He said, 'Observation'.", "\"Now, I would never have thought that was going to be the answer. I said, 'Well, why do you think you need that?', and he said, 'Because a horse can't talk'.", "\"Incredible answer.\"", "
'My favourite place'
", "Since watching the 1956 Olympic Games in Melbourne as a young kid growing up in suburban Australia, there has not been a sporting event or personality that has escaped Sheedy's attention.", "Yet, his greatest thinking is done away from the stadia and arenas that have dominated his life.", "\"I think that the Botanic Gardens was my favourite place [as a kid],\" he said.", "\"When I was in Prahran and South Yarra \u2026 it was very poor in some areas.", "\"We had seven children, and mum and dad in a very small house \u2014\u00a0that's nine people \u2014 so I always wanted a garden.", "\"I bought an acre \u2026\u00a0so that taught me that one day if you ever get the chance, go and build your own garden and make it similar to what you always loved.", "\"There was not a lot of money in Australia. Forget about two-car families.\u00a0We never had television, we had radio, and if you ever thought you could have a transistor you were a very wealthy young kid.", "\"I reckon the thing I loved about our young country at that time was the MCG \u2026 and the Olympic Games in 1956.", "\"It was an inspiration for our country to get that from mainly Europe and other Pacific nations \u2026 I think they (International Olympic Committee) must have wanted it a long, long way away from war-torn nations of the world.", "\"I don't know how they made that decision, so I try and look back on making decisions like that \u2014\u00a0how do you think that far ahead? And these are the sorts of things I grew up with.", "\"I had beautiful parents and fantastic friends, and [with] the paperboy rounds I had I got to meet Australia walking the streets, catching trams and trains, selling newspapers \u2026 I loved it.\"", "", "
Sheedy (left) \u2014 pictured with his 2000 premiership captain James Hird \u2014 maintains his love of Australian rules.(AAP: Joe Castro)
", "If Sheedy could come back and do it all again, would it be any different? Would he be different?", "\"Wow,\u00a0gee. That's a big question or two,\" Sheedy\u00a0said.", "\"[Personally] I don't want to be any more than what I am. Money is OK, too much is ridiculous.", "\"To me, if you've got a lot of money out there \u2014\u00a0the billionaires, the multimillionaires \u2014\u00a0just give some back to the people that don't have any, somehow. Work it out.\"", "Firm. Succinct. Solution focused. Sheedy has spent a lifetime looking for winning formulas. This is just the latest."]
